text: Deep biue sky overhead. Fat, scuddy clouds. Below them, black and white cows graze the rolling hills. This could one of those California “It’s The Cheese” commercials. Except those commercials don’t normally focus on cow shit We do. TILT DOWN to a fat, round PATTY drying olive drab the sun. Flies buzz. Peaceful and quiet. Until... ++» ZOOOM! WHEELS plow right through the shit with a SPLA

Is speeding smack-dab through the pasture, no road in sig A bit out of place, to say the least. It’s an old 70's er Winnebago with chalky white paint and Bondo spots. A bump sticker for the Good Sam Club is stuck to the back. The Winnebago galumphs across the landscape, scattering c It catches a wheel and sprays a rooster tail of red dirt.

Inside, the DRIVER’s knuckles cling white to the wheel. H got the pedal flat. Scared, breathing fast. His eyes bug wide behind the faceplate of his gas mask. Oh, by the way, he’s wearing a GAS MASK. That, and white jockey UNDERPANTS. Nothing else. Buckled in the seat beside him lolls a clothed PASSENGER, also wearing a gas mask. Blood streaks down from his ear, blotting his T-shirt. He’s passed out cold. Behind them, the interior is a wreck. Beakers and buckets and flasks -- some kind of ad-hoc CHEMICAL LAB -- spill t noxious contents with every bump we hit. Yellow-brown liq washes up and down the floor. It foams in a scum around.. ++. Two DEAD BODIES. Two freshly deceased Mexican guys tumble like rag dolls, bumping into each other. Completing this picture is the blizzard of MONEY. A Von’s bag lies leaking twenties. Fifteen, twenty grand in cash wafts around in the air or floats in the nasty brown soup CLOSE on the driver’s eyes. He’s panting like a steam engine. His mask FOGS UP until finally he can’t see. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

The Winnebago comes roaring over a berm and down into a d gully. Too deep. BAM! The front bumper bottoms out, burying itself. WAAAAAAH! The rear wheels spin air. The engine cuts off. Silence again. The Winnie’s door kic open and out stumbles underpants man. He yanks off his ga mask, lets it drop. He’s forty years old. Receding hairline. A bit pasty. He’s not a guy who makes a living working with his hands. He’s not a guy we’d pay attention to if we passed him on street. But right now, at this moment, in this pasture? Right now, we’d step the fuck out of his way. Underpants man looks at the RV. End of the line for that. He listens hard. Out of the silence, we hear... SIRENS. They’re faint, a few miles off -- but growing louder. Our guy knows he’s boned with a capital B. He HOLDS HIS BREAT and leaps back inside the RV.

A chrome 9mm is clutched in the hand of one of the dead Mexicans. Underpants grabs it, tucks it in his waistband. His unconscious passenger, still strapped in his seat, le out a groan. Underpants leans past him, yanks open the gl box. He comes up with a WALLET and a tiny Sony CAMCORDER.

Ducking outside, he starts breathing again. A short sleev DRESS SHIRT on a hanger dangles from the Winnebago’s awni Underpants pulls it on. He finds a clip-on tie in the pocket, snaps it to his collar. No trousers, unfortunatel He licks his fingers, slicks his hair down with his hands He’s looking almost pulled together now -- at least from waist-up. All the while, the sirens are getting LOUDER. Underpants figures out how to turn on the camcorder. He twists the little screen around so he can see himself in Framing himself waist-up, he takes a moment to gather his thoughts... then presses RECORD. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Belmont Avenue, Ontario, California 91764. I am of sound mind. To all law enforcement entities, this is not an admission of guilt. I’m speaking now to my family. (swallows hard) : Skyler... you are... the love of my life. I hope you know that. Walter Junior. You’re my big man. I should have told you things, both of you. I should have said things. But I love you both so much. And eur unborn child. And I just want you to know that these... things you‘re going to learn about me in the coming days. These things. I just want you to know that... no matter what it may look like... I had all three of you in my heart. The sirens are WAILING now, on top of us. WALTER WHITE, t underpants man, turns off the camcorder. He carefully set it on a bare patch of ground by his feet. Next to it he s his wallet, lying open where it can be seen. CLOSE ON the wallet -- a photo ID card is visible. Walt’s smiling face is on it. It identifies him as a teacher at J.P. Wynne High School, Ontario Unified School District. Walt pulls the chrome pistol from the back of his waistba aiming it across the tall weeds. It glints hard in the su Flashing red LIGHT BARS speed into view, skimming the top the weeds. Heading straight for us. Walt stands tall in his underpants, not flinching. Off hi ready to shoot the first cop he sees...
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

No president ever slept here. No millionaire ever visited This is a three-bedroom RANCHER in a modest neighborhood. Weekend trips to Home Depot keep it looking tidy, but it‘ never make the cover of “Architectural Digest.” We're in Ontario, California -- the Inland Empire. LEGEND “ONE MONTH EARLIER.”

Dark and silent. SKYLER WHITE, late 30s, sleeps peacefull Beside her, her husband Walter is wide awake. Walt reaches over and presses a button on his Sharper Ima alarm clock. It projects the time in glowing blue numbers the cottage cheese ceiling: 5:02 AM. Walt lies motionless. Brain churning. He presses the butt again, staring straight up. 5:02 turns to 5:03. Close enough. Walt rises without waking his wife. He exit

We hear an 0o.S. SQUEAK-SQUEAK as we drift through this r We pass an empty crib, Pampers, a baby monitor still in i box. There’s going to be a new addition to the family. We come upon the source of the SQUEAKING. It’s Walt balan on a Lillian Vernon stair-stepper, just three easy paymen of $29.95. Walt plods up and down in the darkness like he marching to Bataan.

Walt sits down on the edge of the tub. We’re watching his face in the bathroom mirror. He masturbates. Judging by h expression, he might as well be waiting in line at the DM Walt double-takes, catching sight of himself. Distracted, examines the sallow bagginess under his eyes. He draws at the loose skin under his chin. Staring at himself long and hard, Walt loses his erection He gives up trying, pulls up his sweat pants. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

Walt is dressed for work ~~ Dockers and a short-sleeve dr shirt courtesy of Target. An American flag pin on his tie He and Skyler eat their breakfast in silence. Skyler glances up, sees Walt puzzling over his bacon.
Sizzle-Lean. We need to think about our cholesterol.

Huh. Skyler’s cute in a way most guys wouldn't have noticed ba in high school. But not soft-cute. Not in the eyes. She’s dressed for staying home -- she’s five months pregn and just beginning to show.
When’11 you be home?
Same time.

I don’t want him dicking you around tonight. You get paid till six, you work till six. Not seven. Seventeen year-old WALTER, JR. enters the kitchen, dresse for school, hair still damp from the shower. The CLICK... CLICK of his forearm crutches precedes him into the room. Walt and Skyler’s son is a sweet-faced teenager who appea to have cerebral palsy. He moves slowly and awkwardly, an grinds his teeth as he labors to talk. But he’s a smart k
Hey. Just seating himself at the table is a trial for Walter, His parents don’t give him the slightest help. They treat him as if he were able-bodied, which is how he wants it.

You’re late. He shrugs. She gets up, serves him breakfast. Walter, Jr. squints at the plate she plops down before him. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  WALTER, JR. What 's—--that?
Sizzle-lean. We‘re watching our cholesterol. WALTER, JR. Not--me! I want-~bacon!
Eat it. Walter, Jr. picks at his breakfast, annoyed. WALTER, JR. What’s this--even--made of?! He looks to his dad for backup. Walt shrugs, ambivalent.
Eat it.

J.P. Wynne High School. Home of the Fightin’ Skyhawks. Tw thousand-plus students, many of them in overflow trailers Into the faculty lot motors a 1991 Nissan wagon. It was a piece of shit when it rolled off the assembly line, and h not improved with age. It parks in a handicapped space. A handicapped placard hangs from the rear-view. Walt climbs out from behind the wheel, checks his watch. He‘s late. Walter, Jr. struggles to get out of the passen side. He fumbles with his crutches and his backpack.

All set? (off his son’s nod) Alright, see you at home. Walt grabs his briefcase and hurries toward the building, leaving his son to work it out for himself -- which is, again, exactly how Walter, Jr. wants it. INT. HIGH SCHOOL - CLASSROOM — DAY Hours later. This is a chemistry classroom -- black-toppe lab tables with gas spigots. Walt is lecturing to seniors Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Chemistry is the study of what?
(a beat) Chemicals. Snickers from the smart kids. Walt smiles.

Chemicals. No. Change. Chemistry is the study of change. (a beat) Think about it. Electrons change their orbits, molecules change their bonds. Elements combine and change into compounds. That’s all of life, right? The constant... (shrug) The cycle. Solution, dissolution, over and over. Walt seems to be talking mostly to himself. A pep talk.

Growth, decay. Transformation. It's fascinating, really. Handsome, blonde CHAD sits slouched in the back with his jammed in the lap of his cheerleader GIRLFRIEND. He whisp to her and she giggles. Walt snaps out of it.
Chad, keep your hands to yourself please. Is there something wrong with your own table? Chad sighs heavily and drags his stool back to an adjoini table. Doing so, he makes as much NOISE as he can.
Alright, ionic bonds. Chapter six.

Last period. Wide on Walt in the background, who sits alo in this deserted room. Head down, he grades tests while h eats a sandwich from home. It’s a lonesome tableau. A physics teacher, MARGARET, enters. She’s 30s, redhead, attractive without being pretty. Sexy, more like. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Heya, Walt.

Hey, Margaret. Margaret feeds the soda machine a dollar. Walt stares at back a little too long. We feel his interest. Margaret gets her Diet Coke and turns his way. Walt lower his eyes. Margaret joins him at the table, checks her wat
Happy Birthday.
(surprised) How'd you know? Walt shrugs. Smiles. Margaret does, too.
Thanks. She fumbles in her purse, comes up with a cigarette and lighter. She notices Walt’s surprised glance.
Be a champ, wouldja? Don’t narc.
(amused by the word) My lips are sealed. Margaret lights up and sucks deep. Ohhh yeah. She blows smoke toward the ceiling, gives it a wave with Walt’s pap
Walt, you are my hero. Walt glances up at her once more. She catches him doing i smiles back and holds his look. He drops his eyes first.
Those things’ll kill you, you know. Margaret shrugs, exhales.
Something always does. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
This is one of those 60s Googie-style structures -- faded space-age futuristic. Young Mexicans dry the cars by hand
Walt’s afternoon part-time job. He works the cash registe

-- Eight, nine, ten, and ten makes twenty. Thank you. Come again. The CUSTOMER wanders off, re-counting his change. Walt closes his drawer and busies himself with record keeping. AMIR, the middle-aged Persian owner, argues on the phone.
No. Not -- that is not what I said. What I said to you -- Amir switches to FARSI. The conversation grows more heate Finally, he barks something and hangs up. He turns to Wal
My sister’s worthless son -- piece of shit! Shit! Fired for good this time! (sighs; shrugs) I’11 run the register.
Amir, no. We talked about this. Inside only. And only till six.

I’m short-handed, Walter. What am I to do? What am I to do? Pissed, Walt unclips his tie, shoves it in his breast poc EXT. VELVET-TOUCH CAR WASH — AFTERNOON The sun’s sinking low. Walt -- master’s degree, Inland Empire Science Educator of the Year for ‘92, ‘95, and ‘01 is towel-drying cars alongside the teenage vatos. His sla and shoes are spotted with soapy water. He's grim. Walt is at work on an anthracite BMW 3-Series. As he hunk down to Armor-All the tires, we hear: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  10.

Hey, you missed a spot. Walt looks up to see handsome CHAD smirking down at him. Young master Chad is tickled pink. This is his Beemer, by the way. Chad’s girlfriend stands in b.g., giggling into cell phone. Whispering just loud enough to be heard.
{into phone) Ohmigod. Oh -- my -- God. You are not going to believe... She cups a hand over her mouth, turns away. Walt says nothing. He needs this job. Off him, scrubbing harder...

The speedometer vibrates at 86. Walt is alone in the car, speeding home. Tired and dirty. He’s swallowed a lot of anger today. It’s way down deep, but it glows inside him. The needle creeps up to 91. Things rattle and shake. Walt eyes fix on something ahead. Walt’s POV -- through the windshield, it’s a straight sho down the freeway. A mile ahead of us is a TRIPLE OVERPASS It’s a graceful, swooping thing made of ribbons of white concrete. It rises up out of the flatlands as we approach dwarfing everything for miles around. Walt studies it. He lets off the gas a little. Cars crawl the overpass, over and under each other. Endle strings of white headlights, red taillights. This giant structure routes them in every direction a person can tra Something about it distracts Walt. Occupies him. Walt coasts underneath it all, staring up at it through h sunroof. Once he’s past it, he speeds up again. He eyes i in his rearview mirror, then leaves it behind.
Walt’s Sentra chugs into the driveway, parking behind a s new VOLVO SUV. Staring at the Volvo, Walt is not happy.

Oh, shit. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  11. The front door of Walt's house opens. Out steps a big, barrel-chested man with a bourbon in one hand. This is HA Walt’s brother-in-law. Hank raises his glass hello. He ta his watch and shakes his head -- you're late. EXT. APPLEBEE’S - NIGHT Deep suburbia. The shiny Volvo SUV is parked in foregroun INT. APPLEBEE’S - NIGHT Family night in this chain restaurant. Walt, Skyler and Walter, Jr. sit in a corner booth with Hank and his wife MARIE. Marie is Skyler's sister. We see the resemblance.
Amir, this guy’s name is? Jesus. Call Homeland Security.
Hank...

I’m serious. Call the FBI, see if he’s legal. Might not be. Ship his ass back to Camel-Land. Hank shoots a winning grin at his nephew. Walter, Jr. sno with delight as he chews a mouthful of hamburger.
(flat) I don’t know, Hank. Do they actually have camels in Iran?
No. Horses. Arabian stallions.

Arabian what? Jesus. Camels, horses -- a towel-head is a towel-head. You’re missing my... (interrupts himself) ... And they’re not Arabian anyway, they're Persian. But you're missing my point here. This guy is treating your husband like uh, you know. Door mat. Here Walt is, got a brain the size of Wisconsin and he’s shampooing dried cum outta some teenager's back seat? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  12.
Hank --
(to Walter, Jr.) Sorry. You didn’t hear that. (to Walt) You say the word, I’ll go talk to this guy. I‘1l set him straight. Walt gives a pained little smile, shakes his head.
You sure? Happy to do it.

No. Thank you. Let's, please, let’s change the subject. Hank shrugs and drains his beer. He winks at Walter, Jr., who grins. The teenager worships his fire-pisser uncle. Walt can’t help but notice. Hank is everything Walt isn’t bold, brash, confident. Skyler sips her white wine. Marie stares at her.
You’re sure it's okay to drink.
After the first trimester, yes. It was even in “Newsweek.”
Well, I didn’t see that. Marie disapproves. Prickly. Hank’s eyes are on the bar Tv

Oh, hey! Turn it up! Hank WHISTLES. The college-age BARTENDER glances at him, confused, Hank hustles over and keys up the volume on the nearest TV SET. They're all wired together. Everybody in the restaurant, like it or not, has to listen to... »+. The local news. HANK, the man himself, is being interviewed on television. He’s polished and official. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  13.

-- At which point we apprehended three individuals and placed them in custody. I'm proud to say that the outstanding professionalism shown by my fellow agents of the San Bernardino District Office resulted in a substantial quantity of methamphetamine being taken off the street. An on-screen graphic identifies him as “AGENT HENRY WELD, D.E.A.” The real-live Hank gives a smile and a nod, not j to his family, but to everyone in the place. Such is the force of his will that strangers APPLAUD him. Walter, Jr. holds up a hand, which Hank high-fives. WALTER, JR. Damn. TV does-~add ten pounds.

Ah hah-hah. Sit and spin. Hank rubs the corner of his mouth with his middle finger, flipping off Walter, Jr. They’re like two teenagers. Walt eats french fries and tries his best to tune everyon out. Something on TV catches his eye. It's the spoils of this drug bust. Laid out on a table ar bags and bags of crystal meth and several guns. But also. eight big SHOBBOXES full of CASH. Walt chews his food, watches. Despite himself...
Hank? How much money is that?
Almost seven hundred thousand. Pretty good haul. The TV lingers on fat rolls of $20s rubber-banded togethe It’s more currency than Walt has ever seen outside of a h movie. He’s surprised.
That’s got to be unusual, right? That kind of cash? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  14.

Mmm. Not the most we ever took. (to the room) There’s no deficit of total morons in the drug trade. And they can make a ton of money, too. At least until we catch ‘em. But we catch ‘em eventually. Hank flashes his great smile around the room. He notes Walt’s continued interest in the news report. Likes it.

Walt, just say the word and 1'11 take you on a ride-along. You can watch us knock down a meth lab. (good-natured) ‘Less that’s too much excitement for you. Walt forces a pained grin and shrugs -- maybe someday.
The lights are off. It’s late.

Walt, dressed for bed in sweats and a t-shirt, checks him out in the bathroom mirror. He’s not loving what he sees. He pulis at the skin under his eyes. He COUGHS a little. In the bedroom, Skyler’s in her nightgown, sitting at the computer. She’s following the final moments of an auction eBay. Walt pads into the room, sits down beside her.
Which one’s this?
(eyes on the screen) That faux-Lalique vase I picked up at the flea market.
How's it doing?

I met my reserve and there’s still two minutes. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  15. Walt nods, sits watching. Without taking her eyes off the screen, Skyler reaches over and slips a hand into Walt’s sweatpants. Walt smirks, surprised.
What’s up?
You tell me. Skyler plays with him, out of sight below frame. A beat.
What are you doing tomorrow?
(shrug) Actually, I was thinking about, um. Maybe drive to Caltech.
You’re not gonna mow?
Yeah, I’1ll mow. JPL’s got an exhibit of Mars rover photographs. Supposed to be, the detail... just really amazing. Really beautiful.
I just need you to mow at some point. I'’d do it myself, except it always throws rocks at me. I think it needs a new bag.
I will mow. First thing. Skyler glances at Walt’s crotch. Good-~naturedly:
What’s going on down there? Is he asleep?
I’m just... we gotta be careful of the baby.

Don’t worry about the baby. This is for you. We’re only doing you tonight. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  16. Obscured by the computer, Skyler gives Walt a vigorous handjob with one hand and works the mouse with the other.
Just relax. Just... close your eyes and let it... Skyler glances again at her husband. Apparently, there's mighty oak sprung from whence the lowly acorn lies.
Just close your eyes. Walt does so, concentrating. Trying hard. Tugging away, Skyler’s attention drifts back to the computer. Completel
--- That’s it. That’s... it. There you go. Keep going. Keep going. Keep it going. Keep... (reacting to the screen) Yes! Fifty-six. Walt’s eyes open. The thrill is gone.
Old Pasadena. Wide greenbelts and dark magnolias. The sig says “Jet Propulsion Laboratory.” Einstein was a visiting professor at Caltech, once upon a time. This place looks

MARS fills frame, stark red rocks and red sand. We PAN OF this blow-up of Martian terrain -- we’re in a hallway mou with two dozen such photos, big and striking. Small in the distance stands Walt. He’s not looking at an of these photos. He’s down an adjacent hallway, staring a something else, instead.

He's studying names engraved on an old plaque. It’s a lis of grad students awarded a particular research grant. Closer. “ORGANIC CHEMISTRY, 1988 -- Walter H. White.” Walt stares at his own name on the plaque. We can’t read thoughts, but we can guess at them. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  17.

An outdoor snack bar. Walt sits alone. Around him, young STUDENTS pore over textbooks or quietly type on laptops. Walt sips his coffee and stares into space. At the nearest table, a CHINESE GUY sits with two CHINESE GIRLS. They’re laughing and talking in CANTONESE. They ke their voices low so their gossip might not be overheard - but it’s not like we have any idea what they’re saying. Walt takes another sip of coffee, carefully sets down the cup. He looks at his hand for a long moment. He notices his fingers are TREMBLING slightly. He makes a fist, squeezes it tight. Opens it. The Asian students are talking a mile-a-minute, the two g giggling. Walt glances at them, looks back to his hand. H presses it flat against the tabletop. UP-ANGLE -- as seen through this GLASS TOP TABLE, Walt's fingers stick to the surface. They pull loose with a slow gluey SLURP. CLOSER on Walt. He rubs his mouth, sneaks his fingertips his carotid artery just under his ear. He’s feeling his pulse. The furtive whispering in CHINESE fills his head. He's starting to breathe faster. His cellphone RINGS. He glances at the readout screen. “HOME,” it says. Walt silences it, tucks the phone back i his pocket. Rapid~fire CHINESE is all we hear. Now it gets drowned ou by a sudden WHOOSH that makes Walt blink. It’s the whoosh the nearby cappuccino machine. It’s unnaturally loud, lik jet engine. Walt’s had enough. Time to go.

Magnolia leaves sway in f.g. We're looking down at Walt, tiny in the distance, as he rises to his feet. He makes i three steps before he COLLAPSES, flipping an empty table. Students look up, hesitate. The Chinese guy and a couple others rise to help. Off Walt, lying on his face...
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  18.

INT. ER - EXAM ROOM — DAY Walt is conscious, seems okay. He sits in a blue paper go legs dangling off an exam table. He’s alone, waiting. Absently tapping the table. He’s been here for hours. Muffled RINGING. Walt reaches for his pants, fishes out h cellphone. “HOME” is yet again displayed on the readout. Walt considers, answers it.

Hey. (a beat) Yeah, sorry. TI had it turned off. I was, uh... (a beat) Yeah, probably about an hour or so. Amid the bustle out in the hall, two ER DOCTORS stand conferring. They’re looking at blood chemistry results -- first one man studies them, then the other. When one of t glances back our way, we realize they’re talking about Wa Walt sees this. He can’t hear what they’re saying, but it looks weighty. Walt is anxious. However, he doesn’t let i come through in his voice.

I'm at Caltech. I ran into an old professor, we got to talking. I should be home in about an hour. Okay. Walt clicks off. He looks again to the doctors in the hal One man nods to the other, walks off. The remaining docto puts on his bedside smile and enters Walt’s room.
Sorry for the wait. You can put your clothes back on. Walt climbs off the table, steps into his pants.

I’ve had it before. Low blood sugar. Stood up too fast. He's fishing. The doctor doesn’t saying anything, just fi out a form. Walt pulls on his shirt, buttons it. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Guess I should’ve had breakfast this morning.

There’s a specialist I’d like you to see. His name is Dr. Belknap. I should have his... card here somewhere. Yes. The doctor finds a business card, hands it to Walt. Walt stands in his socks, staring at the card for a long beat.
Oncologist...
(forced breezy) It’s probably absolutely nothing.

Days later. A MONTAGE OF CLOSE-UPS: a blood pressure cuff gets pumped with a WHOOSH-WHOOSH-WHOOSH; a stethoscope sl here and there over bare skin; glands get palpated; blood drawn; eyes, ears, nose and throat are checked; more bloo drawn; colorful MRIs pop up on a monitor; still more BLOO drawn. END MONTAGE. cUT TO —- Walt in his street clothes, sitting in a red leather chair. He's staring almost directly into camera. SILENCE. Up from it rises a faint sort of buzzy, shimmeri TINNITUS sound. It’s the RINGING in Walt’s ears. It gets louder as we slowly CREEP IN on Walt’s face. He‘’s starin us blankly. He’s staring at: Walt’s POV -- DOCTOR BELKNAP. Dr. Belknap is a balding ma in his late fifties. On a good day, he’s maybe avuncular. He’s sitting behind his desk, looking right at us, talkin slight SLOW-MOTION. We don’t hear a single word he’s sayi We only hear the buzzy RINGING. CLOSER POV -- we tilt down from Belknap’s face, his movin lips, to his doctor’s coat. On the pristine white of his lapel, there's a spot of yellow MUSTARD. We fixate on it. Suddenly:

-- Mr. White? Are you listening? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  20. We’ve snapped out of it. The SOUND in the room is normal. No more SLOW-MOTION. Walt looks up from the man’s lapel.
Yeah.
Did you..?. You understoed what I’ve said to you?

Yeah. Multiple myeloma. Stage 3. (a beat) Best-case scenario, with chemo, I‘ll live another two years. (off the man‘s gaze) It’s just, you’ve got mustard on your... you’ve got mustard there. Walt points. Belknap glances down at the spot on his lape then back up at Walt. He has no idea what to say to that. Off Walt, looking very matter-of-fact... disconcertingly

Same clothes, same day -- Walt came to work straight from getting his terrible news. He’s on autopilot, standing behind the cash register. The BUZZ is back in his head. Amir is in the b.g., arguing on the phone in sound is muted. We can barely hear him. We he’s yelling about anyway -- it’s pointless, We’re on Walt, who simply stares into space. Farsi. The don’t know what doesn’t matter. No customers. Walt suddenly jerks, like a tiny zap of electricity goes through him. He steps out from behind th counter and exits. Amir doesn’t notice him leave. As seen through the windows, Walt pads along like a zombie and nearly gets run over by a car. The vatos all watch, confused, as Walt climbs in his Nissan and drives away. INT. NISSAN SENTRA —- DRIVING - EVENING Walt drives. Not speeding. No expression on his face. His POV: it’s a straight shot up the 10 Freeway. The familiar TRIPLE OVERPASS looms ahead in the distance. Walt stares at it like it’s the monolith in ”2001.” Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  21.
An AERIAL VIEW, looking straight down at this vast and complex concrete knot. Walt’s tiny Nissan is an ant trundling toward it. The car disappears from view underneath, as if being swallowed.
A glass of white wine. Skyler stands talking on the phone
(into phone) Absolutely. I sent it to you on the third. It’s number... wait a minute, let me get my checkbook. She cups a hand over the phone, does nothing. After a bea

(into phone) Here it is. It’s check number 1148. So my records show I paid that, and I certainly don’t feel like we owe any late... (listens) Alright. I guess then I’1] check with my bank and, I don’t know, if the post office lost it or something... alright then. Let me look into that. Thank you. Walt enters, hearing the tail-end. Skyler hangs up.

You're home early. Walt nods, finds a beer in the fridge. His fingers trembl little as he pries off the cap. Skyler doesn’t notice -- she’s sifting through a stack of bills. Walt sits at the table. He drinks deep, rubs his mouth.
How was your day?
You know. Samé. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  22.
Don’t tell me Amir’s sending you home at five now.
No, just. Today.
(studying a bill) Did you use the MasterCard last month? $15.88 at Staples?
Uh. We needed printer paper.

Walt, the MasterCard’s the one we don’t use. Walt nods, overwhelmed and hiding it. Skyler doesn’t know about his doctor’s appointment. Even if Walt wants to tel her, something stops him. He sips his beer, stares. Loud MACHINE GUN FIRE startles them both. Skyler yells in the living room.
(more GUNFIRE) Go talk to him. Walt rises, sets his bottle in the sink.

-- Whatever it is, I’1ll1 tell you this. I do not like it when you don’t talk to me. The worst thing you can do is shut me out.

I'm... I understand. I’m fine. She stares at him in the darkness. He stares at her. A strange feeling comes over him. It’s relief to be alive mixed with dread that life won’t last. It’s fear of being caught. It’s the thrill -- for once -- of taking risks. It’s excitement, in many different forms. And since he ca talk about it, there’s only one way to let it out. Walt kisses his wife. Passionately.
